private_information: Role: manipulator agent that can pick up, put down, stack and unstack blocks one at a time
Local perception: initial positions relevant to me are A on table, B on J, C on table, D on F, E on A, F on C
worker1.goal: Track the effects of the given action sequence on the subset of blocks I perceive and produce a concise stepwise state trace for those blocks

private_information: Role: manipulator agent that can pick up, put down, stack and unstack blocks one at a time
Local perception: initial positions relevant to me are G on table, H on I, I on G, J on table, and B on J
worker2.goal: Track the effects of the given action sequence on the subset of blocks I perceive and produce a concise stepwise state trace for those blocks

orchestrator.goal: Integrate observations from workers and the action sequence to produce a PDDL domain and PDDL problem suitable for the FastDownwards solver that encodes the final arrangement of all blocks as the planning goal

public_information: Classic Blocks World rules apply: only the top block of a stack may be moved and only one block can be carried at a time
There are ten blocks labeled A B C D E F G H I J

Initial arrangement: A is on the table, B is on top of J, C is on the table, D is on top of F, E is on top of A, F is on top of C, G is on the table, H is on top of I, I is on top of G, J is on the table

Action sequence to execute in order: 1. unstack(B, J) 2. stack(B, J) 3. unstack(B, J) 4. stack(B, E) 5. unstack(H, I) 6. putdown(H) 7. pickup(J) 8. stack(J, B) 9. unstack(J, B) 10. stack(J, D) 11. unstack(I, G) 12. putdown(I) 13. pickup(G) 14. putdown(G) 15. unstack(J, D) 16. stack(J, B) 17. pickup(G) 18. stack(G, I) 19. pickup(H) 20. stack(H, D) 21. unstack(J, B) 22. putdown(J) 23. unstack(G, I) 24. stack(G, B) 25. unstack(H, D) 26. putdown(H) 27. pickup(H) 28. stack(H, I) 29. unstack(D, F) 30. stack(D, F)

Goal for the orchestrator: derive the final arrangement after applying the action sequence to the initial arrangement and encode that arrangement as the goal in a PDDL problem compatible with FastDownwards

observe.system_prompt: You are worker1. You are not required to emit PDDL. Using the public information and your private information, produce a concise stepwise state trace for the blocks you perceive. For each action in the sequence that affects your blocks, indicate the effect and the resulting local configuration. Return a compact structured summary that a coordinator can consume.
observe.prompt: You are worker1. Public information: {environment->public_information}. Your private information: {agents->worker1->private_information}. Your goal: {agents->worker1->goal}. Process the action sequence and output a concise structured trace of states for the blocks you observe. Do not output PDDL.

observe.system_prompt: You are worker2. You are not required to emit PDDL. Using the public information and your private information, produce a concise stepwise state trace for the blocks you perceive. For each action in the sequence that affects your blocks, indicate the effect and the resulting local configuration. Return a compact structured summary that a coordinator can consume.
observe.prompt: You are worker2. Public information: {environment->public_information}. Your private information: {agents->worker2->private_information}. Your goal: {agents->worker2->goal}. Process the action sequence and output a concise structured trace of states for the blocks you observe. Do not output PDDL.

pddl.system_prompt: You are the orchestrator. Your task is to integrate worker observations and the public action sequence to produce a complete PDDL domain and a PDDL problem file that encode the final arrangement as the planning goal. Target the FastDownwards solver. Provide a STRIPS-compatible PDDL domain and a PDDL problem suitable for FastDownwards. Enclose the domain between <domain></domain> tags and the problem between <problem></problem>. Keep agent actions and any agent-specific predicate names distinct if needed.
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. Public information: {environment->public_information}. Worker 1 observation: {obs_worker1}. Worker 2 observation: {obs_worker2}. Your goal: {agents->orchestrator->goal}. Using the initial arrangement and the action sequence, determine the final arrangement of all blocks and produce a PDDL domain and PDDL problem compatible with FastDownwards that has the final arrangement as the goal. Enclose the pddl domain between <domain></domain> and the pddl problem between <problem></problem>.
